image.altText: Destruction from Cyclone Tracy on Daly St

props.synopsis: Cyclone Tracy and its total destruction of Darwin prompted a national overhaul of the National Construction Code. But some building industry experts argue it doesn't provide enough protection.

title.children: Experts warn building codes still fall short following Cyclone Tracy

image.altText: Young woman surrounded by pets

props.synopsis: Some emergency shelters don't allow pets during a cyclone. The RSPCA is urging pet owners to include their furry friends in emergency planning this wet season.

title.children: Humans go to cyclone shelters – but what about pets?

image.altText: Sea cucumbers

props.synopsis: The Australian Border Force seized 500 kilograms of sea cucumbers and 1,000 kilograms of salt over the weekend as part of a crackdown on illegal fishing in the Northern Territory

title.children: Illegal fishers found with 500kg of sea cucumbers in NT waters

image.altText: Aboriginal woman in purple shirt sitting in chair

props.synopsis: When the ABC visited Alpurrurulam, a tiny outback town on the Northern Territory-Queensland border, all anyone in town wanted to talk about was what was happening at the local school.

title.children: Allegations of bullying and inappropriate behaviour at outback school

image.altText: A close up on a two-month-old baby's face, with its right hand on its cheek.

props.synopsis: The family of a baby injured in a shocking home invasion in Alice Springs thanks the community for its support after a fundraiser drew more than $52,000 in donations.

title.children: $52,000 raised for baby injured in Alice Springs home invasion

image.altText: A woman in a black top sits on her couch

props.synopsis: Territorians are copping rent rises as high as 60 per cent while some are finding themselves on the street due to no-fault evictions and a lack of options for those doing it tough.

title.children: No-fault evictions leave NT renters at risk of homelessness

image.altText: A woman with a backpack on stands between two trees and presses her hands to them.

props.synopsis: The ABC speaks to those who took alternative and complementary medicines after a cancer diagnosis and how they navigated their beliefs.

title.children: Cancer patient kept $10k in 'treatment' secret from her medical team

image.altText: A close-up of Jim Chalmers's face.

props.synopsis: The government's mid-year budget update is bereft of even the slightest whiff of pre-election razzamatazz — which makes it rather strange by the standards of budget politics.

title.children: Chalmers wants you to immediately forget this budget update ever happened

image.altText: Headshots of the two men side by side.

props.synopsis: Australia asks Malaysia for assurances that two men who admitted conspiring in the Bali bombings will be closely monitored following their release and repatriation.

title.children: Australia 'seeking assurances' as Bali bombing duo released from Guantanamo Bay

image.altText: Pina colada

props.synopsis: A toxicology report into the suspected alcohol poisonings at Fiji's Warwick Resort that left four Australians critically ill has found no traces of methanol.

title.children: 'No methanol' found in Fiji alcohol poisoning that hospitalised Australians

image.altText: Woman vlogging at home with Christmas tree behind.

props.synopsis: A relatively new type of advertising is seeing "explosive growth" due to converging trends in consumer behaviour, with industry experts saying this Christmas will be the biggest ever for affiliate marketers.

title.children: Hidden commissions behind this year's Christmas gift guide boom

image.altText: John in a library

props.synopsis: Acclaimed children's author John Marsden raised generations of children through his bestselling books and the schools he founded.

title.children: John Marsden had no biological children but raised generations of kids

image.altText: Twenty small ziplock backs containing different shaped and coloured pills and powders.

props.synopsis: NSW will begin a pill testing trial at music festivals from early 2025 in what it says will help combat the risks and harms associated with using illicit drugs.

title.children: NSW to begin pill testing trial at music festivals from early 2025

image.altText: daughter holding photo

props.synopsis: Sonja Kurtzer was a "trailblazing feminist" who inevitably lost her identity in an attempt to seek "spiritual healing". Now, her daughter Ellen Bertani is on a quest for justice.

title.children: Ellen's mum sought 'spiritual healing', then stopped counselling and medication

image.altText: A silver four-wheel-drive vehicle with its front end squashed under a collapsed building roof with debris scattered around

props.synopsis: Vanuatu's tourism businesses say visitors will play a major role in its post-earthquake recovery, when the country is ready for them.

title.children: Vanuatu tourism operators hope Australians will help post-quake recovery

image.altText: Three large metal structures in a paddock with cows.

props.synopsis: The federal government has green-lit a southern NSW project that will form a key part of its plan to connect more renewable energy to the grid.

title.children: Controversial $4.8b Snowy 2.0 transmission project gets federal approval

image.altText: two women sitting at a table looking through documents

props.synopsis: It's been a long and exhausting journey, and even a legally-binding order made by a civil tribunal may not have brought their fight to an end.

title.children: 'We just want to have long service leave': Workers' long fight for entitlements

image.altText: Penny Wong during a media conference.

props.synopsis: Israeli media is reporting the country's Foreign Minister, Gideon Sa'ar, blasted Penny Wong during a phone call on Tuesday, accusing Australia of abandoning Israel in its most difficult year.

title.children: Penny Wong plays down 'heated' call with Israeli counterpart

image.altText: Travis Head plays a pull shot while three Indian fielders watch on

props.synopsis: Australia and India have to settle for an inevitable draw at the Gabba, but not before a wild session of play on day five raised a few more untimely questions for the Aussie batters.

title.children: Australia counts the gifts and the gaffes from a very silly Gabba Test

image.altText: A man and a woman in blue spacesuits pose for a photo, smiling.

props.synopsis: The delay means what should have been an eight-day stay on the International Space Station for Suni Williams and Butch Wilmore will now be at least nine months.

title.children: Return of NASA astronauts from ISS further delayed until late March

image.altText: Close up of a white chihuahua's face in focus, with a blurred vet injecting a vaccine in background

props.synopsis: Vets are urging pet owners to vaccinate their dogs against the deadly parvovirus, as cases in unvaccinated dogs rise in one regional Victorian community.

title.children: Pet vaccine misinformation rising following COVID-19 pandemic, vets say

image.altText: A flooded regional road.

props.synopsis: Heavy rain has led Queensland authorities to issue an emergency alert for South Burnett, where some roads have been cut by flash flooding.

title.children: Emergency alert issued after flooding in Queensland

image.altText: Damien Richardson speaking

props.synopsis: A former actor known for his roles on Blue Heelers, Neighbours and McLeods Daughters has been charged by Victoria Police for performing a Nazi salute.

title.children: Victoria Police charge former Neighbours star over performing Nazi salute

image.altText: A female judge poses for a photo in the courtroom, with a large Indigenous artwork in the backdrop.

props.synopsis: Supporters of the Koori Court say the informal setting and discussions with Indigenous elders can have a transformative effect, steering people away from a life of crime.

title.children: In this court, straight-talking justice is served up in a bid to change lives

image.altText: A Queensland police officer operating a roadside speed camera

props.synopsis: From Friday, double demerit points will be applied by a number of states around the country. But in many other jurisdictions, it will be business as usual.

title.children: Drivers in some states can get double demerit points over summer break

image.altText: Two woman and a man holding a tablet look at another man

props.synopsis: Laid was the uniquely Aussie story of a woman whose exes start mysteriously dying. Now the Americans have got their hands on it.

title.children: Laid proves that Americans should leave Aussie sitcoms alone

image.altText: A close up photo of Nicolas Sarkozy at an official event.

props.synopsis: Sarkozy had been appealing a 2021 ruling that found him guilty of illegal attempts to secure favours from a judge.

title.children: Former French president to wear tracking tag after 'corruption pact'

image.altText: Jennah Halley

props.synopsis: Women employed in electrical trades has increased by 65 per cent since 2020 in Australia, according to the Powering Skills Organisation.

title.children: Number of women in electrical trades in Australia up 65 per cent since 2020

image.altText: A Foodbank meal service.

props.synopsis: With interest rates holding firm and the cost-of-living biting hard, charities across Sydney are trying to keep up with increased demand from people facing food insecurity.

title.children: Sydney charities struggle with rising demand as cost-of-living bites

image.altText: A man holds up a plastic bag that has a canister in it.

props.synopsis: The canister, which likely fell from a passing ship, was suspected to contain a chemical commonly used in pesticides and fumigants.

title.children: Clean-up crew finds toxic canister washed up on Victorian beach

image.altText: An ancient axe next to a ruler

props.synopsis: A South Australian teacher who collected hundreds of objects starting in the 1960s is now trying to sell them, but Indigenous leaders say they should instead be put on display in a "keeping place" that doesn't yet exist.

title.children: Sale of large collection of South Australian Aboriginal artefacts opposed

image.altText: A man in a collared shirt looks forward.

props.synopsis: ACT senator David Pocock said it happened but now a former Services Australia employee says his toilet breaks were monitored.

title.children: 'Dehumanising': Former Services Australia employee claims toilet breaks were timed

image.altText: A bird covered in oil along a beach, surrounded by oil slicks.

props.synopsis: Thousands of volunteers are working to clean up oil slicks along sandy beaches in Russia after two stricken tankers spilled oil into the Black Sea.

title.children: Russian authorities declare state of emergency over Black Sea oil spill

image.altText: Two men in colourful suits look serious as they speak to each other in a hallway.

props.synopsis: A British court has ruled that police can seize more than $4 million to cover years of unpaid taxes from "manosphere" influencer Andrew Tate and his brother Tristan.

title.children: UK police to seize more than $4m in unpaid taxes from Andrew Tate

image.altText: A hand in a white rubber glove holding a black ball.

props.synopsis: Balls of chemicals and waste were first found at Coogee in October, then at Kiama in November. Now the debris is turning up even further south, causing beach closures during the far south coast's peak tourism period.

title.children: Mystery balls wash up on beaches 300km from Sydney, threatening tourism
